trans-unit.source: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component
trans-unit.target: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component

trans-unit.source: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.
trans-unit.target: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.

trans-unit.source: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component
trans-unit.target: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
trans-unit.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
trans-unit.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

trans-unit.source: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.
trans-unit.target: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.

trans-unit.source: However, if your component consists of many files, installation can be tedious for your users.
trans-unit.target: However, if your component consists of many files, installation can be tedious for your users.

trans-unit.source: Also, errors in placing files or failure to set references might cause problems for them.
trans-unit.target: Also, errors in placing files or failure to set references might cause problems for them.

trans-unit.source: You can package a complex component as a Visual Studio extension SDK, to make it easy to install and use.
trans-unit.target: You can package a complex component as a Visual Studio extension SDK, to make it easy to install and use.

trans-unit.source: Users only need to set one reference for the entire package.
trans-unit.target: Users only need to set one reference for the entire package.

trans-unit.source: They can easily locate and install your component by using the **Extensions and Updates** dialog box, as described in [Finding and Using Visual Studio Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/vstudio/dd293638.aspx), in the MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: They can easily locate and install your component by using the **Extensions and Updates** dialog box, as described in [Finding and Using Visual Studio Extensions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/vstudio/dd293638.aspx), in the MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: Planning a distributable Windows Runtime Component
trans-unit.target: Planning a distributable Windows Runtime Component

trans-unit.source: Choose unique names for binary files, such as your .winmd files.
trans-unit.target: Choose unique names for binary files, such as your .winmd files.

trans-unit.source: We recommend the following format to ensure uniqueness:
trans-unit.target: We recommend the following format to ensure uniqueness:

trans-unit.source: Your binary files will be installed in app packages, possibly with binary files from other developers.
trans-unit.target: Your binary files will be installed in app packages, possibly with binary files from other developers.

trans-unit.source: See "Extension SDKs" in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx), in the MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: See "Extension SDKs" in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx), in the MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: To decide how to distribute your component, consider how complex it is.
trans-unit.target: To decide how to distribute your component, consider how complex it is.

trans-unit.source: An extension SDK or similar package manager is recommended when:
trans-unit.target: An extension SDK or similar package manager is recommended when:

trans-unit.source: Your component consists of multiple files.
trans-unit.target: Your component consists of multiple files.

trans-unit.source: You provide versions of your component for multiple platforms (x86 and ARM, for example).
trans-unit.target: You provide versions of your component for multiple platforms (x86 and ARM, for example).

trans-unit.source: You provide both debug and release versions of your component.
trans-unit.target: You provide both debug and release versions of your component.

trans-unit.source: Your component has files and assemblies that are used only at design time.
trans-unit.target: Your component has files and assemblies that are used only at design time.

trans-unit.source: An extension SDK is particularly useful if more than one of the above are true.
trans-unit.target: An extension SDK is particularly useful if more than one of the above are true.

trans-unit.source: **Note** For complex components, the NuGet package management system offers an open source alternative to extension SDKs.
trans-unit.target: **Note** For complex components, the NuGet package management system offers an open source alternative to extension SDKs.

trans-unit.source: Like extension SDKs, NuGet enables you to create packages that simplify the installation of complex components.
trans-unit.target: Like extension SDKs, NuGet enables you to create packages that simplify the installation of complex components.

trans-unit.source: For a comparison of NuGet packages and Visual Studio extension SDKs, see [Adding References Using NuGet Versus an Extension SDK](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj161096.aspx) in the MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: For a comparison of NuGet packages and Visual Studio extension SDKs, see [Adding References Using NuGet Versus an Extension SDK](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj161096.aspx) in the MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: Distribution by file copy
trans-unit.target: Distribution by file copy

trans-unit.source: If your component consists of a single .winmd file, or a .winmd file and a resource index (.pri) file, you can simply make the .winmd file available for users to copy.
trans-unit.target: If your component consists of a single .winmd file, or a .winmd file and a resource index (.pri) file, you can simply make the .winmd file available for users to copy.

trans-unit.source: Users can put the file wherever they want to in a project, use the **Add Existing Item** dialog box to add the .winmd file to the project, and then use the Reference Manager dialog box to create a reference.
trans-unit.target: Users can put the file wherever they want to in a project, use the **Add Existing Item** dialog box to add the .winmd file to the project, and then use the Reference Manager dialog box to create a reference.

trans-unit.source: If you include a .pri file or an .xml file, instruct users to place those files with the .winmd file.
trans-unit.target: If you include a .pri file or an .xml file, instruct users to place those files with the .winmd file.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Visual Studio always produces a .pri file when you build your Windows Runtime Component, even if your project doesn't include any resources.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Visual Studio always produces a .pri file when you build your Windows Runtime Component, even if your project doesn't include any resources.

trans-unit.source: If you have a test app for your component, you can determine whether the .pri file is used by examining the contents of the app package in the bin\\debug\\AppX folder.
trans-unit.target: If you have a test app for your component, you can determine whether the .pri file is used by examining the contents of the app package in the bin\\debug\\AppX folder.

trans-unit.source: If the .pri file from your component doesn't appear there, you don't need to distribute it.
trans-unit.target: If the .pri file from your component doesn't appear there, you don't need to distribute it.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use the [MakePRI.exe](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/jj552945.aspx) tool to dump the resource file from your Windows Runtime Component project.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use the [MakePRI.exe](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/jj552945.aspx) tool to dump the resource file from your Windows Runtime Component project.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the Visual Studio Command Prompt window, type: makepri dump /if MyComponent.pri /of MyComponent.pri.xml You can read more about .pri files in [Resource Management System (Windows)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/jj552947.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For example, in the Visual Studio Command Prompt window, type: makepri dump /if MyComponent.pri /of MyComponent.pri.xml You can read more about .pri files in [Resource Management System (Windows)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/jj552947.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Distribution by extension SDK
trans-unit.target: Distribution by extension SDK

trans-unit.source: A complex component usually includes Windows resources, but see the note about detecting empty .pri files in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: A complex component usually includes Windows resources, but see the note about detecting empty .pri files in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: To create an extension SDK
trans-unit.target: To create an extension SDK

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have the Visual Studio SDK installed.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have the Visual Studio SDK installed.

trans-unit.source: You can download the Visual Studio SDK from the [Visual Studio Downloads](https://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/download-visual-studio-vs) page.
trans-unit.target: You can download the Visual Studio SDK from the [Visual Studio Downloads](https://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/download-visual-studio-vs) page.

trans-unit.source: Create a new project using the VSIX Project template.
trans-unit.target: Create a new project using the VSIX Project template.

trans-unit.source: You can find the template under Visual C# or Visual Basic, in the Extensibility category.
trans-unit.target: You can find the template under Visual C# or Visual Basic, in the Extensibility category.

trans-unit.source: This template is installed as part of the Visual Studio SDK.
trans-unit.target: This template is installed as part of the Visual Studio SDK.

trans-unit.source: ([Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C# or Visual Basic](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj127119.aspx) or [Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C++](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj127117.aspx), demonstrates the use of this template in a very simple scenario.
trans-unit.target: ([Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C# or Visual Basic](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj127119.aspx) or [Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C++](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj127117.aspx), demonstrates the use of this template in a very simple scenario.

trans-unit.source: Determine the folder structure for your SDK.
trans-unit.target: Determine the folder structure for your SDK.

trans-unit.source: The folder structure begins at the root level of your VSIX project, with the **References**, **Redist**, and **DesignTime** folders.
trans-unit.target: The folder structure begins at the root level of your VSIX project, with the **References**, **Redist**, and **DesignTime** folders.

trans-unit.source: **References** is the location for binary files that your users can program against.
trans-unit.target: **References** is the location for binary files that your users can program against.

trans-unit.source: The extension SDK creates references to these files in your users' Visual Studio projects.
trans-unit.target: The extension SDK creates references to these files in your users' Visual Studio projects.

trans-unit.source: **Redist** is the location for other files that must be distributed with your binary files, in apps that are created by using your component.
trans-unit.target: **Redist** is the location for other files that must be distributed with your binary files, in apps that are created by using your component.

trans-unit.source: **DesignTime** is the location for files that are used only when developers are creating apps that use your component.
trans-unit.target: **DesignTime** is the location for files that are used only when developers are creating apps that use your component.

trans-unit.source: In each of these folders, you can create configuration folders.
trans-unit.target: In each of these folders, you can create configuration folders.

trans-unit.source: The permitted names are debug, retail, and CommonConfiguration.
trans-unit.target: The permitted names are debug, retail, and CommonConfiguration.

trans-unit.source: The CommonConfiguration folder is for files that are the same whether they're used by retail or debug builds.
trans-unit.target: The CommonConfiguration folder is for files that are the same whether they're used by retail or debug builds.

trans-unit.source: If you're only distributing retail builds of your component, you can put everything in CommonConfiguration and omit the other two folders.
trans-unit.target: If you're only distributing retail builds of your component, you can put everything in CommonConfiguration and omit the other two folders.

trans-unit.source: In each configuration folder, you can provide architecture folders for platform-specific files.
trans-unit.target: In each configuration folder, you can provide architecture folders for platform-specific files.

trans-unit.source: If you use the same files for all platforms, you can supply a single folder named neutral.
trans-unit.target: If you use the same files for all platforms, you can supply a single folder named neutral.

trans-unit.source: You can find details of the folder structure, including other architecture folder names, in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx), in the MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: You can find details of the folder structure, including other architecture folder names, in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx), in the MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: (That article discusses both platform SDKs and extension SDKs.
trans-unit.target: (That article discusses both platform SDKs and extension SDKs.

trans-unit.source: You may find it useful to collapse the section about platform SDKs, to avoid confusion.
trans-unit.target: You may find it useful to collapse the section about platform SDKs, to avoid confusion.

trans-unit.source: Create an SDK manifest file.
trans-unit.target: Create an SDK manifest file.

trans-unit.source: The manifest specifies name and version information, the architectures your SDK supports, .NET Framework versions, and other information about the way Visual Studio uses your SDK.
trans-unit.target: The manifest specifies name and version information, the architectures your SDK supports, .NET Framework versions, and other information about the way Visual Studio uses your SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can find details and an example in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can find details and an example in [How to: Create a Software Development Kit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh768146.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Build and distribute the extension SDK.
trans-unit.target: Build and distribute the extension SDK.

trans-unit.source: For in-depth information, including localizing and signing the VSIX package, see VSIX Deployment in the MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: For in-depth information, including localizing and signing the VSIX package, see VSIX Deployment in the MSDN Library.
